case_vignette: a 28-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with shortness of breath and chest pain, 35 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision. he was the helmeted driver of a scooter hit by a truck. on arrival, he is alert and oriented with a glasgow coma scale rating of 14. his temperature is 37.3°c (99.1°f), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 33/min and blood pressure is 132/88 mm hg. pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. examination shows multiple abrasions over his abdomen and extremities. there is a 2.5-cm (1-in) laceration on the left side of the chest. there are decreased breath sounds over the left base. cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. the abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation over the left upper quadrant. bowel sounds are normal. his hemoglobin concentration is 13.6 g/dl, leukocyte count is 9,110/mm3, and platelet count is 190,000/mm3. a chest x-ray is shown.
question: which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm experiencing shortness of breath and chest pain.
How long have these symptoms been occurring?
The symptoms started about 35 minutes ago.
Do you have any existing heart conditions or a history of heart disease in your family?
No, I don't have any existing heart conditions or a history of heart disease in my family.
Are you currently on any medications or have any other medical conditions?
No, I am not on any medications or have any other medical conditions.
Does the pain worsen when you breathe deeply or cough?
Yes, the pain worsens when I breathe deeply or cough.
Have you experienced any recent injuries to your chest or ribs?
Yes, I was involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision recently.
**Final Diagnosis:** Traumatic pneumothorax
